values.title: Don't embed full version in installed paths

content.raw:
We want to avoid changing tutorials and making users change scripts every time we make a release.  So, don't put package-x.y.z in installed path.  Either:

* pull back to x.y (i.e., imply compatibility across patchlevels for given major/minor)
OR
* don't embed path at all

Same goes for Gazebo.
content.html:
We want to avoid changing tutorials and making users change scripts every time we make a release. So, don't put package-x.y.z in installed path. Either:

  • pull back to x.y (i.e., imply compatibility across patchlevels for given major/minor) OR
  • don't embed path at all

Same goes for Gazebo.

content.raw:
In drcsim's `cmake/setup.sh.in`, we have this line:

        unset GAZEBO_MODEL_DATABASE_URI

It was put there as a quick hack to allow the DRC kickoff tutorial to proceed without time-consuming network access on startup.  But it required manual cloning the gazebo model database into the user's `~/.gazebo/models` directory.

That unset should be removed.

Also, the underlying issue with Gazebo's access to the online model database [gazebo issue 54](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/54/gazebo-should-time-out-quickly-on) should be addressed.
content.html:
In drcsim's cmake/setup.sh.in, we have this line:

    unset GAZEBO_MODEL_DATABASE_URI

It was put there as a quick hack to allow the DRC kickoff tutorial to proceed without time-consuming network access on startup. But it required manual cloning the gazebo model database into the user's ~/.gazebo/models directory.

That unset should be removed.

Also, the underlying issue with Gazebo's access to the online model database gazebo issue 54 should be addressed.

content.raw: When one displays both stereo camera images using the rviz "Camera" display, the images themselves appear to be rendered from the correct viewpoints. When projecting objects back into the camera image however, the right camera seems to use the camera frame of the left camera. See attached image.

When projecting objects back into the camera image however, the right camera seems to use the camera frame of the left camera. See attached image.

values.title: DRC Terrain texture warps when gazebo camera viewpoint changes

content.raw: The DRC terrain seems to use some shader for rendering the texture. When the user changes the viewpoint of the gazebo gui camera, the terrain often seems to move/warp relative to the gray grid overlay, although both the grid and the textured terrain are at the exact same elevation. This is confusing and will be even more confusing for stereo and VSLAM algorithms (provided the same warping also happens for simulated cameras, not verified).
content.html: The DRC terrain seems to use some shader for rendering the texture. When the user changes the viewpoint of the gazebo gui camera, the terrain often seems to move/warp relative to the gray grid overlay, although both the grid and the textured terrain are at the exact same elevation. This is confusing and will be even more confusing for stereo and VSLAM algorithms (provided the same warping also happens for simulated cameras, not verified).

content.raw:
The updated model files in the latest release of the drc sim define the mesh axis as Y_UP (r_uleg.dae, l_clav.dae, r_clav.dae). While gazebo assumes all files are Z_UP, in order to import the model to our own simulation we need the axis to be defined as Z_UP. 

Also, the updated files seem to be without texture.

values.title: Inertia of certain links is very large

content.raw:
Several links are defined in the drc_robot model with the following inertia and mass properties


```
mass = 0.1 kg
ixx = 0.01 kg m^2
iyy = 0.01 kg m^2
izz = 0.01 kg m^2
```

Assuming that the link is a ellipsoid of uniform density, the length of the semi-principle axes can be calculated using (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipsoid#Dynamical_properties). This elipsoid will reduce to a sphere with a radius of 0.5m, which is way larger than the link itself.

I've attached a plot of the inertia ellipsoid of the individual links offset from the robot model. The links that have non-realistic inertia data are
```
mtorso (mass = 0.55, ixx=iyy=izz=0.1, radius=0.6742m)
[l,r]_palm (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)
[l,r]_f[0,1,2]_0 (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)
[l,r]_f[0,1,2]_1 (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)
[l,r]_f[0,1,2]_2 (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)
[l,r]_uglut (mass = 0.5166, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.31m)
[l,r]_uglut (mass = 0.69, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.2692)
[l_r]_talus (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)
```

So, it seems to be the hands and some connecting links in the torso an the talus. 

(in the urdf, a seperate (l,r)_f(0,1,2)_(0,1,2)_accel link is defined for the fingers. The mass and inertia of this link is added to the finger link when you use gazebo to export to SDF).

In our previous simulations, we estimated the inertia of some links by assuming it is an ellipsoid of uniform density that is about the same size as the real link.
content.html:
Several links are defined in the drc_robot model with the following inertia and mass properties

mass = 0.1 kg
ixx = 0.01 kg m^2
iyy = 0.01 kg m^2
izz = 0.01 kg m^2

Assuming that the link is a ellipsoid of uniform density, the length of the semi-principle axes can be calculated using (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipsoid#Dynamical_properties). This elipsoid will reduce to a sphere with a radius of 0.5m, which is way larger than the link itself.

I've attached a plot of the inertia ellipsoid of the individual links offset from the robot model. The links that have non-realistic inertia data are

mtorso (mass = 0.55, ixx=iyy=izz=0.1, radius=0.6742m)
[l,r]_palm (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)
[l,r]_f[0,1,2]_0 (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)
[l,r]_f[0,1,2]_1 (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)
[l,r]_f[0,1,2]_2 (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)
[l,r]_uglut (mass = 0.5166, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.31m)
[l,r]_uglut (mass = 0.69, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.2692)
[l_r]_talus (mass = 0.1, ixx=iyy=izz=0.01, radius = 0.5m)

So, it seems to be the hands and some connecting links in the torso an the talus.

(in the urdf, a seperate (l,r)f(0,1,2)(0,1,2)_accel link is defined for the fingers. The mass and inertia of this link is added to the finger link when you use gazebo to export to SDF).

In our previous simulations, we estimated the inertia of some links by assuming it is an ellipsoid of uniform density that is about the same size as the real link.

values.title: setup.sh doesn't allow use of a ros overlay and drcsim at the same time

content.raw:
The title isn't great, but basically I would like the setup.sh broken into different files. 

Right now I am running a ROS Overlay, and if I source either the setup.sh in my overlay or the setup.sh from drcsim, they will clobber each others set ROS_PACKAGE_PATH. 

I was able to get it working fine if I created my own drcsim setup.sh file that just had "step 1" commented out, and source it after I've sourced my overlay's setup.bash.
content.html:
The title isn't great, but basically I would like the setup.sh broken into different files.

Right now I am running a ROS Overlay, and if I source either the setup.sh in my overlay or the setup.sh from drcsim, they will clobber each others set ROS_PACKAGE_PATH.

I was able to get it working fine if I created my own drcsim setup.sh file that just had "step 1" commented out, and source it after I've sourced my overlay's setup.bash.

content.raw:
the model.sdf for the drc_robot is not actually an sdf model but rather uses urdf. Either rename it to .urdf or convert it to sdf.

The problem with having the model in urdf is that for example multiple collision models per link aren't supported and are discared when parsing to sdf.

The problem with sdf on the other hand is that it's not backwards compatible with urdf and hence rviz can't load and visualize it.
content.html:
the model.sdf for the drc_robot is not actually an sdf model but rather uses urdf. Either rename it to .urdf or convert it to sdf.

The problem with having the model in urdf is that for example multiple collision models per link aren't supported and are discared when parsing to sdf.

The problem with sdf on the other hand is that it's not backwards compatible with urdf and hence rviz can't load and visualize it.

content.raw:
As pointed out by Chris[1] the BDI cfg to urdf parser is dropping bits resulting in a loss in precision (although negligible probably, but still not good). The soft limits also shouldn't be set outside the hardware limits.

[1]http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/405/drcsim-loss-of-dynamics-parameters-accuracy/
content.html:

content.raw:
~~~
Here's how I can cause the crash
-- start Atlas DRC simulation and start simulating
-- in terminal:
	rostopic pub -1 /mode std_msgs/String '{data: "nominal"}'
	rostopic pub -1 /mode std_msgs/String '{data: "pinned"}'
	rostopic pub -1 /mode std_msgs/String '{data: "nominal"}'

-- simulation crashes after last rostopic pub --
~~~
content.html:
Here's how I can cause the crash
-- start Atlas DRC simulation and start simulating
-- in terminal:
    rostopic pub -1 /mode std_msgs/String '{data: "nominal"}'
    rostopic pub -1 /mode std_msgs/String '{data: "pinned"}'
    rostopic pub -1 /mode std_msgs/String '{data: "nominal"}'

-- simulation crashes after last rostopic pub --

values.title: continous joint is not limited to [ 0 : 2*pi ]

content.raw:
I've added a continuously spinning joint with a laser - for the DRC robot's head to my own model:


```
#!c++

  <joint name="head_hokuyo_joint" type="continuous">
    <origin rpy="0 0 0" xyz="0 0 0"/>
    <axis xyz="1 0 0"/>
    <parent link="head"/>
    <child link="head_hokuyo"/>
    <limit effort="5" velocity="12"/>
    <safety_controller k_position="100.0" k_velocity="100.0" soft_lower_limit="-9.2146" soft_upper_limit="10.7854"/>
    <dynamics damping="0.1" friction="0"/>
  </joint>
```

However when i query the angle when spinning clockwise:

```
#!c++

double current_position = it->second->GetAngle(0).GetAsRadian();
```

... the angle is not limited to [ 0 : 2* pi].
And after some time is a value in the 100s. There seems to be no wrap around here.

This is probably a bug in gazebo itself.

However when i query the angle when spinning clockwise:

This is probably a bug in gazebo itself.

values.title: gazebo_ros_api should set ros time directly rather than publishing /clock topic

content.raw:
see [ros::Time::setNow(const Time & new_now)](http://www.ros.org/doc/api/rostime/html/classros_1_1Time.html#ab569bffab97380d8a73275cdc02afb8f).

Possibly add a signal to `World::Update()` whenever sim time is updated, call `SetSimTime` and evoke a signal (set by gazebo_ros_api) to update ros time.
content.html:
see ros::Time::setNow(const Time & new_now).

Possibly add a signal to World::Update() whenever sim time is updated, call SetSimTime and evoke a signal (set by gazebo_ros_api) to update ros time.

content.raw:
Currently the DRC Vehicle plugin controls the steering of the front wheels based on the measured hand-wheel angle. This does not allow force feedback from the wheels to be felt at the steering wheel.

If proper steering feel is necessary for the VRC, the model should be enhanced. Specifically, the model should have:

* Rack and pinion steering linkage
* Reasonable steering kinematics (kingpin and caster angles)
* Reasonable tire friction model
content.html:
Currently the DRC Vehicle plugin controls the steering of the front wheels based on the measured hand-wheel angle. This does not allow force feedback from the wheels to be felt at the steering wheel.

If proper steering feel is necessary for the VRC, the model should be enhanced. Specifically, the model should have:

  • Rack and pinion steering linkage
  • Reasonable steering kinematics (kingpin and caster angles)
  • Reasonable tire friction model

content.raw:
The lidar's range should be [0.1,30] instead of [0.08,10]. The lidar's angular resolution should be 0.25, right now it's 0.281 (180/640) - at the current measurement range of 180 deg you need 720 samples instead of 640 to get a resolution of 0.25. In theory the lidar's full field of view would be 270 degree (with 1080 samples) but given that the kick-off drawing also only has a 180 degree fov BDI/CR might be limiting it to 180deg?

Also, the spindle speed setting should consider the real hardware's limitations (1.25 to 50 RPM afaik).
content.html:
The lidar's range should be [0.1,30] instead of [0.08,10]. The lidar's angular resolution should be 0.25, right now it's 0.281 (180/640) - at the current measurement range of 180 deg you need 720 samples instead of 640 to get a resolution of 0.25. In theory the lidar's full field of view would be 270 degree (with 1080 samples) but given that the kick-off drawing also only has a 180 degree fov BDI/CR might be limiting it to 180deg?

Also, the spindle speed setting should consider the real hardware's limitations (1.25 to 50 RPM afaik).

values.title: Can not reliably pin & unpin robot to world

content.raw:
While I'm not entirely sure what the cause of this is, I am trying to make the robot move around (with base pinned, using the /cmd_vel topic), unpin the robot, perform some motion, and when completed, move again using the /cmd_vel topic. 

However, what I am experiencing is that the robot's hip will remain pinned after the second time the robot has moved around, which causes our action to have the robot perform it while floating in the air.
content.html:
While I'm not entirely sure what the cause of this is, I am trying to make the robot move around (with base pinned, using the /cmd_vel topic), unpin the robot, perform some motion, and when completed, move again using the /cmd_vel topic.

However, what I am experiencing is that the robot's hip will remain pinned after the second time the robot has moved around, which causes our action to have the robot perform it while floating in the air.

content.raw:
There's an incorrect RPY offset listed for the IMU attached to the pelvis.  I believe this is supposed to be a position offset instead.
```
  <joint name="imu_joint" type="fixed">
    <parent link="pelvis"/>
    <child link="imu_link"/>
    <origin rpy="0.05991527603 0 -0.01415" xyz="0 0 0"/>
  </joint>
```
should probably be 
```
  <joint name="imu_joint" type="fixed">
    <parent link="pelvis"/>
    <child link="imu_link"/>
    <origin xyz="0.05991527603 0 -0.01415" rpy="0 0 0"/>
  </joint>
```

content.raw:
The drcsim robot models that are used by gazebo reside in drcsim/models/drc_robot*/model.urdf

The xacro scripts used to create drc_robot_sandia_hand use drcsim/ros/drc_robot_utils/urdf/drc_robot.urdf, but this appears to be updated less frequently than the model used by gazebo.

When we make changes to the gazebo model, we also need to make changes to the urdf in the ros directory. Even better would be to automatically build the gazebo model from the source urdf so there's only one model in version control. In the meantime, please attempt to update both models.
content.html:
The drcsim robot models that are used by gazebo reside in drcsim/models/drc_robot*/model.urdf

The xacro scripts used to create drc_robot_sandia_hand use drcsim/ros/drc_robot_utils/urdf/drc_robot.urdf, but this appears to be updated less frequently than the model used by gazebo.

When we make changes to the gazebo model, we also need to make changes to the urdf in the ros directory. Even better would be to automatically build the gazebo model from the source urdf so there's only one model in version control. In the meantime, please attempt to update both models.

content.raw: in 1.3.0 rc, we made imu_joint a revolute joint so it does not get reduced by fixed joint reduction.  Either re-outfit AtlasPlugin.cc to take an offset parameter and make pelvis link the imu link, or add a transmission to the imu_joint.
content.html: in 1.3.0 rc, we made imu_joint a revolute joint so it does not get reduced by fixed joint reduction. Either re-outfit AtlasPlugin.cc to take an offset parameter and make pelvis link the imu link, or add a transmission to the imu_joint.

content.html:
Running from prerelease, with

roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch

and

rosrun rviz rviz

configured to view stereo point cloud, cameras and laser scan.

The simulation crashes after about 10 minutes:

(gdb) cont

values.title: vrcplugin errors should not be errors

content.raw:
As of drcsim almost-1.3, I'm getting these errors when launching `atlas.launch`:

    [ERROR] [1356136344.456348129, 0.001000000]: drc vehicle not found.
    [ERROR] [1356136344.456572029, 0.001000000]: fire_hose_model [fire_hose] not found

If the plugin can proceed without those things, then it's not an error.  If it's an error, then we should fix the launch/world file configuration to include the required elements.

content.html: Change MultiSense head to have a synchronized stereo camera pair (i.e. use Gazebo's new MultiCamera sensor).

values.title: multisense plugin (resolution, update rate, stereo alg, ...)

content.raw:
Right now the MultiSenseSLPlugin only supports changing the update rate of the individual cameras but not their resolution (changing the update rate of individual cameras shouldn't be allowed either as they're supposed to be synchronized). 

The MultiSense-SL head seems to support 3 different resolutions and color or monochrome mode at the moment:
```
- Left camera color image plus disparity, 24 bit RGB/BGR at 2048x1088 at 10.6 FPS, 2048x544 at 21.2 FPS, or 1024x544 at 42.4 FPS
- Or Left camera monochrome image plus disparity, 8 bit at 2048x1088 at 15 FPS, 2048x544 at 30 FPS, or 1024x544 at 60 FPS
```
The 4th resolution (VGA) listed in the public pdf is either missing in this list or not supported (yet).


Considering the "left image + disparity" note you might also want to move the disparity calculation inside the MultiSense plugin and  only publish left image + disparity if the MultiSense head only provides the left image and not both. Edit: I just checked with CR and they only return left+disparity due to bandwidth limitations so this should be done the same way on the simulated robot.

Moving disparity calculation inside the MultiSense plugin would also make it easier for you to use a different stereo algorithm other than the current OpenCV CPU Block-Matching inside stereo_image_proc (e.g. OpenCV's Semi-Global Block Matching which would give results closer to MultiSense's Semi-Global Matching but would be quite slow for high resolutions, or OpenCV's GPU implementation of Block Matching to achieve a frame rate closer to MultiSense's ... maybe teams could be free to choose between a slower CPU based SGBM and a faster GPU BM given that both have trade-offs to the real MultiSense head ... unless you're able to come up with a GPU or "fake" implementation that is closer to MultiSense's SGM implementation both precision and speed wise).
content.html:
Right now the MultiSenseSLPlugin only supports changing the update rate of the individual cameras but not their resolution (changing the update rate of individual cameras shouldn't be allowed either as they're supposed to be synchronized).

The MultiSense-SL head seems to support 3 different resolutions and color or monochrome mode at the moment:

- Left camera color image plus disparity, 24 bit RGB/BGR at 2048x1088 at 10.6 FPS, 2048x544 at 21.2 FPS, or 1024x544 at 42.4 FPS
- Or Left camera monochrome image plus disparity, 8 bit at 2048x1088 at 15 FPS, 2048x544 at 30 FPS, or 1024x544 at 60 FPS

The 4th resolution (VGA) listed in the public pdf is either missing in this list or not supported (yet).

Considering the "left image + disparity" note you might also want to move the disparity calculation inside the MultiSense plugin and only publish left image + disparity if the MultiSense head only provides the left image and not both. Edit: I just checked with CR and they only return left+disparity due to bandwidth limitations so this should be done the same way on the simulated robot.

Moving disparity calculation inside the MultiSense plugin would also make it easier for you to use a different stereo algorithm other than the current OpenCV CPU Block-Matching inside stereo_image_proc (e.g. OpenCV's Semi-Global Block Matching which would give results closer to MultiSense's Semi-Global Matching but would be quite slow for high resolutions, or OpenCV's GPU implementation of Block Matching to achieve a frame rate closer to MultiSense's ... maybe teams could be free to choose between a slower CPU based SGBM and a faster GPU BM given that both have trade-offs to the real MultiSense head ... unless you're able to come up with a GPU or "fake" implementation that is closer to MultiSense's SGM implementation both precision and speed wise).

content.raw:
---

From [Gazebo Answers](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/558/update-drcsim-setupsh/):

It would be nice to include
 
    export GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH=/usr/share/drcsim-1.3/models:$GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH

in drcsim-1.x/setup.sh

Currently to access the Atlas meshes we do something like: file://../models/atlas/meshes/ltorso.dae

---

As of drcsim 1.3.0, we do this in `setup.sh`:

    # Step 4: modify Gazebo configuration.
    export GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH=/usr/share/drcsim-1.3/worlds:$GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH
    export GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH=/usr/share/drcsim-1.3/models:$GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH
    export GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH=/usr/lib/drcsim-1.3/plugins:$GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH

Presumably, the setting of `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` was intended to accomplish what's being asked here.  But the [user guide](http://gazebosim.org/user_guide/started__components__env.html) doesn't even list `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`, so perhaps something's gotten out of date.  Or perhaps the `models` directory should be present in both lists and the user guide is missing documentation on `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`.
content.html:
From Gazebo Answers:

It would be nice to include

export GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH=/usr/share/drcsim-1.3/models:$GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH

in drcsim-1.x/setup.sh

Currently to access the Atlas meshes we do something like: file://../models/atlas/meshes/ltorso.dae

As of drcsim 1.3.0, we do this in setup.sh:

# Step 4: modify Gazebo configuration.
export GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH=/usr/share/drcsim-1.3/worlds:$GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH
export GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH=/usr/share/drcsim-1.3/models:$GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH
export GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH=/usr/lib/drcsim-1.3/plugins:$GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH

Presumably, the setting of GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH was intended to accomplish what's being asked here. But the user guide doesn't even list GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH, so perhaps something's gotten out of date. Or perhaps the models directory should be present in both lists and the user guide is missing documentation on GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH.

values.title: Limits on DRC Vehicle cmd messages not checked

content.raw:
Its seems that the values of DRC vehicle command messages are not checked to be in a reasonable range.

So by publishing:
/golf_cart/hand_wheel/cmd = 500
and then:
/golf_cart/hand_wheel/cmd = -500
... causes the steering wheel to turn aggressively and the entire vehicle to **flip over!**
content.html:
Its seems that the values of DRC vehicle command messages are not checked to be in a reasonable range.

So by publishing: /golf_cart/hand_wheel/cmd = 500 and then: /golf_cart/hand_wheel/cmd = -500 ... causes the steering wheel to turn aggressively and the entire vehicle to flip over!

content.raw:
This [tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/drcsim/1.3/VRC_Plugin_Golf_Cart_With_Atlas) suggests we can use the current vehicle for developing the perception elements of driving.

However, the car model is completely different visually versus for collision (see attached still of the actual collision elements). Also LIDAR returns are from the collision model (which is just a sparse plate with wheels) - meaning that perception fusion isn't possible. 

Its not really possible to develop a perception framework when the elements are so different. Can you close the gap between the two models?

Also the visual elements currently chosen for the wheel and pedals are unnecessarily difficult. In particular the wheel is a single featureless wheel with no fiducials. Could this be changed to something like a typical steering wheel:
http://us.123rf.com/400wm/400/400/yanas/yanas1112/yanas111200009/11831005-steering-wheel-on-a-white.jpg

Or could visual markers be added - as in the attached image?

However, the car model is completely different visually versus for collision (see attached still of the actual collision elements). Also LIDAR returns are from the collision model (which is just a sparse plate with wheels) - meaning that perception fusion isn't possible.

Its not really possible to develop a perception framework when the elements are so different. Can you close the gap between the two models?

Also the visual elements currently chosen for the wheel and pedals are unnecessarily difficult. In particular the wheel is a single featureless wheel with no fiducials. Could this be changed to something like a typical steering wheel: http://us.123rf.com/400wm/400/400/yanas/yanas1112/yanas111200009/11831005-steering-wheel-on-a-white.jpg

Or could visual markers be added - as in the attached image?

values.title: wrist and ankle force torque sensors

content.raw:
Enable wrist and ankle force torque sensors for Atlas robot.  See pull request #74.

Note this breaks if using gazebo 1.2, so we should add the patch to 1.2 as well.

This is not really a gazebo style sensor, but a way to fill in data needed by the Atlas wrist and ankle force torque sensor in a model plugin.  For real gazebo style force torque sensor, stay tuned to [this ticket](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/379/create-a-force-torque-sensor).
content.html:
Enable wrist and ankle force torque sensors for Atlas robot. See pull request #74.

Note this breaks if using gazebo 1.2, so we should add the patch to 1.2 as well.

This is not really a gazebo style sensor, but a way to fill in data needed by the Atlas wrist and ankle force torque sensor in a model plugin. For real gazebo style force torque sensor, stay tuned to this ticket.

values.title: Branch drcsim_1.0 is broken with gazebo-1.3.1 and default

content.html:
Branch 1.0 is currently broken with gazebo-1.3.1. Probably, at any time, gazebo change the name of a header from physics.h to physics.hh. Branch drcsim_1.0 is using the .h and it does not exists anymore.

Fix is easy with a one liner in the top directory:

find \( -name "*.h" -o -name "*.hh" \) -exec sed -i -e 's:physics.h":physics.hh":g' {} \;

values.title: Infer ROS distro from environment during configure

content.raw:
Currently we set `ROS_DISTRO` manually in `CMakeLists.txt`.  That value ends up in the installed `setup.sh`.  We should be able to infer the distro from the environment during configure (because the user must have source a ROS setup file).

We were just tripped up by this because were compiling against Groovy but hadn't changed the `ROS_DISTRO` setting.

The same thing should be addressed in `sandia_hand` and `osrf_msgs`.
content.html:
Currently we set ROS_DISTRO manually in CMakeLists.txt. That value ends up in the installed setup.sh. We should be able to infer the distro from the environment during configure (because the user must have source a ROS setup file).

We were just tripped up by this because were compiling against Groovy but hadn't changed the ROS_DISTRO setting.

The same thing should be addressed in sandia_hand and osrf_msgs.

content.raw:
As discussed in the comments to Nate's reply at http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/925/multiple-materials-per-link/ Atlas' textures are not being loaded in Gazebo. This can be solved by adding material scripts just like for the other textured models but while trying to do so I ran into the problem of most parts (esp. the legs) requiring multiple textures and I only managed to load one (someone with more knowledge about Ogre material scripts can probably solve this faster).

The textures show up in rviz without any additional material scripts so while both Gazebo and RViz are based on Ogre, RViz' collada importer seems to be able to handle material properties embedded into the collada files better than Gazebo's does.
For example one of the collada trees from google warehouse loads up with textures and colors without any additional material scripts while the Atlas model is completely blank (even the color on the MultiSense head is missing and needs to be added through separate material tag/script in the sdf file).

It would make the process of creating new models a lot easier if Gazebo would be able to handle all the material properties embedded into the collada file without the need to write separate material scripts. According to Nate's comment this seems to be the desired behaviour anyway and Atlas seems to be supposed to show up as textured already so it's a bug and not a feature request.

values.title: Request ability to reset integral term in JointCommand PID control

content.html:
related to question http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/985/drcsim-five-related-questions-to-api-and/

The joint command message allows general PID control.

I presume the code will be similar to :

err = (position-measured_position);
Int += ki*err*dt;
Int = clamp(Int, min_effort, max_effort);
Output = effort + kp*err + Int + kd*(err - old_err)/dt + kp_vel*(velocity - measured_velocity);
Output = clamp(Output, min_effort, max_effort);

In the event that we want to switch control modes, which is extremely likely for drcsim, we need a way to reset the internal integral term ("Int").

At a minimum, we should be able to zero out the integral term, but allowing arbitrary values is better IMHO. This will allow a user to generate a "bumpless" control when switching control modes.

One challenge that I see it will be the need to coordinate this reset with a new joint command. Resets will occur less frequently than regular joint commands, which points to making this a separate command but raises the issue of synchronization. One might make a special service call that includes both joint command and reset message.
This may also prove useful to avoid the issue of reset getting lost if multiple commands are received between simulation time steps due to asynchronous control updates.

values.title: Request to provide integral "tie-back" during control saturation

content.html:
related to #91 and question http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/985/drcsim-five-related-questions-to-api-and/

The joint command message allows general PID control.

I presume the code will be similar to :

err = (position-measured_position);
Int += ki*err*dt;
Int = clamp(Int, min_effort, max_effort);
Output = effort + kp*err + Int + kd*(err - old_err)/dt + kp_vel*(velocity - measured_velocity);
Output = clamp(Output, min_effort, max_effort);

Any time the control output saturates (clamped), the integral term can "wind up", which leads to unresponsive controls.
Industrial controls that use PID, typically "tie back" the integral term if the controller becomes saturated.

If Output is clamped, the integral term is recalculated as

Int = Output - effort - kp*err - kd*(err - old_err)/dt - kp_vel*(velocity - measured_velocity)
Int = clamp(Int, min_effort, max_effort);

This change avoids integral windup, and leads to more responsive control.

values.title: Improve Texture Visuals for DRC Terrain Model

content.raw:
The test world recommended by the DRC userguide (drc_sim_v0) is not suitable for proper testing of driving or walking scenarios due to 

  - the current multisense camera parameters (far clipping of 100)
  - persisting texture visualization bugs that have been reported more than two months ago (e.g. https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/239/bug-when-reading-common-dae-for-collision ).
  - low resolution ground texture + bad texture filtering (e.g. no anistropic filtering which would help keeping the ground texture sharp[er]).
  - heightmap is rendered lower than its geometry actually is is (due to a flat normal map being applied causing a constant offset to the actual geometry) ... when driving across the heightmap using the polaris ranger I also had fun bugs where the polaris was driving 5m or so in the air above the heightmap.


To visualize the problem here two pictures of a modified drc_sim_v0 world:

  - camera view in gazebo: http://i.imgur.com/lYDF1uP.jpg
  - atlas's camera view: http://i.imgur.com/7zi1PIF.jpg

As you can see the textures for the factory are missing (see above mentioned ticket), the ground texture is very low resolution and bad texture filtering makes this even worse (I know it's just a proof of concept world but I'm mainly mentioning this for consideration when designing the actual worlds), the robot can only see for a very short distance, when using smooth roads the road texture gets stretched very far which causes it to become very blurry (again, for future consideration when designing new worlds), and when moving the camera or doing stereo the heightmap terrain appears to be farther way than it actually is.

Also, given that we're talking about textures already, it would be good to bake lighting effects (shading, ambient occlusion, ...) into the model's textures in order to improve visual quality (important for perception algorithms). Atlas and the new ranger model are very good examples for this.
content.html:
The test world recommended by the DRC userguide (drc_sim_v0) is not suitable for proper testing of driving or walking scenarios due to

  • the current multisense camera parameters (far clipping of 100)
  • persisting texture visualization bugs that have been reported more than two months ago (e.g. https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/239/bug-when-reading-common-dae-for-collision ).
  • low resolution ground texture + bad texture filtering (e.g. no anistropic filtering which would help keeping the ground texture sharp[er]).
  • heightmap is rendered lower than its geometry actually is is (due to a flat normal map being applied causing a constant offset to the actual geometry) ... when driving across the heightmap using the polaris ranger I also had fun bugs where the polaris was driving 5m or so in the air above the heightmap.

To visualize the problem here two pictures of a modified drc_sim_v0 world:

  • camera view in gazebo: http://i.imgur.com/lYDF1uP.jpg
  • atlas's camera view: http://i.imgur.com/7zi1PIF.jpg

As you can see the textures for the factory are missing (see above mentioned ticket), the ground texture is very low resolution and bad texture filtering makes this even worse (I know it's just a proof of concept world but I'm mainly mentioning this for consideration when designing the actual worlds), the robot can only see for a very short distance, when using smooth roads the road texture gets stretched very far which causes it to become very blurry (again, for future consideration when designing new worlds), and when moving the camera or doing stereo the heightmap terrain appears to be farther way than it actually is.

Also, given that we're talking about textures already, it would be good to bake lighting effects (shading, ambient occlusion, ...) into the model's textures in order to improve visual quality (important for perception algorithms). Atlas and the new ranger model are very good examples for this.

values.title: Sandia error on startup when launching without hands

content.raw:
Launching `atlas_utils/atlas.launch`, I consistently get this error in the startup output:

    1: [ERROR] [1359094603.526979237]: sandia hand not present, plugin not loaded

Looks like it's because the `SandiaHandPlugin` is included in `atlas_description/urdf/atlas.gazebo`:

        <plugin name="sandia_hand_plugin" filename="libSandiaHandPlugin.so"/>

Ideally the inclusion of that plugin could be moved somewhere else, to a sandia-specific file.  But maybe we're trying not to fork this file and are instead including all potentially used plugins in it, which is fine.

In that case, we still don't want warnings or errors on normal startup, so the message should be reduced to an INFO.
